fields.description:
reference: http://extranet.atlassian.com/x/_QPFYw

    *  When the assignee initiates the "Request Review" action, a review would automatically created in Crucible, including all change sets associated to the issue and not previously included in another Review associated with this issue.
    * The workflow transition would allow the assignee to enter a comment, which would be included both in the Review's statement-of-purpose and as a JIRA comment.
    * The Review statement-of-purpose would also include the commit messages of each changeset as well as a link to the issue.
    * The assignee would be allowed to select additional reviewers.
    * The assignee would be set as the moderator.
    * When the review is completed by the moderator, Crucible would ask the moderator whether the JIRA issue should be resolved or reopened and allow the moderator to add a comment.
    * Crucible automatically makes the right workflow transition and appends the comment in JIRA.
    * Issues cannot be resolved while there are outstanding reviews. If you attempt to do so, it should remind you to close the outstanding reviews.

All of this should be triggerable as part of a workflow from a svn commit message too (ie if user says #close AOD-123 and the workflow says that the next step is Request Review, it puts the issue into Request Review).
fields.summary: enable Crucible integration to JIRA workflow
switch to jquery

fields.description: timebox to 1d
fields.summary: spec distributed cache for user count

fields.description: Make it look prettier, perhaps by braking on word boundaries only, or doing something clever with the css instead of shortening the names in java.
fields.summary: History drop-down is ugly when compacted

fields.description:
Due to Studio's implementation as cloned virtual machines, we cannot install a JIRA plugin for just one customer - we need to install it in the base virtual machine. This forces us to take a very conservative approach to JIRA plugins, and only install things we're willing to test and fix should they break.

Yet there are plenty of useful JIRA plugins that customers want installed, where the customer is willing to assume risk of future breakage. It would be nice if, like Confluence, we could accommodate these people and allow the installation of plugins for just some customers.

This can be achieved by installing the plugin in the base virtual machine, but having the plugin module disabled by default. For this to work, we need a change in JIRA. Either:
 - when the user clicks the "Enable module" link, display a big warning page stating that this plugin is unsupported and may break in future. We should link to a Confluence page where we can provide our own assessment of the risk to help people decide.
 - prevent end users from accessing the Plugins page, so that enabling a plugin requires Atlassian staff intervention, providing us an opportunity to impress upon people the risks (and perhaps suggest a better alternative).

The intention is to only make third-party functionality available to customers who are well aware of the risks and have explicitly accepted them.
fields.summary: Allow for installation of unsupported JIRA plugins

fields.description: Now that its on top of the tabs, there's no reason to trim it unless its really excessively long. Figure out how max # of characters that doesn't go past the end of the tabs, use that.

for example, if I add a tab called 'downloads' which takes user to a wiki page on the same studio instance with a list of downloads, keep that tab highlighted.
fields.summary: add ability for custom tabs to stay highlighted if internal url

fields.description:
JIRA has a feature dubbed [QuickSearch|http://www.atlassian.com/software/jira/docs/latest/quicksearch.html], a mini search language which lets you do things like:

 - Enter the project key to search for issues in that project (eg. "JST")

 - Enter "my" to indicate issues assigned to the current user

 - Use v: and ff: to search for issues with a particular affects or fix-for version.



It's very useful, and none of it works in Studio.  I particularly miss "JST foo" to search for foo in the JST project.
fields.summary: JIRA QuickSearch no longer works

fields.description: Trac has a useful facility where users can perform actions like automatically closing an issue, just by saying "closes #123" in the Subversion commit message. This is [implemented in a post-commit hook|http://trac.edgewall.org/browser/trunk/contrib/trac-post-commit-hook].  This would be good feature for Studio too, although we would need to deal with more complications due to JIRA's flexible workflow and ability to have required fields.
fields.summary: Let users manipulate JIRA issues via Subversion commit logs

fields.description: A customer has requested the ability to automatically trigger an issue workflow transition when a comment is added. That would require the installation of the [JIRA Toolkit plugin|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRAEXT/JIRA+Toolkit].
fields.summary: Install JIRA Toolkit plugin

fields.description:
If a change occurs in the user count, Conflunce's user counter doesn't update.  Even if the cache is manually flushed and the Conflucence 'License Detalis -> Refresh' button is pushed, the user count remains incorrect.  After 30 minutes or so, the Refresh button works, but if you don't click it, the user count doesn't reset automatically.

It needs to reset automatically and immediately.  Otherwise users cannot save Confluence pages, plus we run into Gliffly licensing issues.
fields.summary: Confluence user counter does not refresh quickly

fields.description: The quick search form tries to search across JIRA, Confluence and Fisheye across all projects.  This is too slow to be practical (eg. 30 seconds).
fields.summary: Full project search too slow

fields.description: In the user browser, if I change a person's email address and click submit, the change doesn't take effect in JIRA. The email address is changed in Crowd, but JIRA is left with the old value, and the old value is used eg. in email notifications.
fields.summary: Changing email address doesn't take effect

fields.description:
Adding users through Administration -> User Browser -> Add User, there is a checkbox to "Send an email to the user you have just created containing their password."

Regardless of whether this checkbox is ticked, Studio does not send the email.
fields.summary: Adding a user does not send email notification

fields.description:

!gliffyerror.png!
fields.summary: Gliffy displays error when non-unlimited license is used

fields.description:
When searching on dev1.jira.com getting an error rather than search results:

"The project you are trying to view does not exist. Try browsing for projects.

If you think this message is wrong, please consult your administrators about getting the necessary permissions. "


If you search for gibberish, and get no results returned, the search "works" (doesn't error, but not very valuable since there are no results).
fields.summary: Search is broken

fields.description:
From James' email:

This will involve a bit of work on our part updating all our test initial data sets (most of the work is in importing the old ones so the upgrade tasks run on them, ensuring it's all good, then exporting them again), as well as updating the initial data set that Contegix uses.  There are two reasons for doing this.  First of all, more than half of the issues I had when upgrading to JIRA 3.13 were problems in the upgrade tasks.  Refreshing the initial data means that we can discard all the upgrade tasks, except for those that are required to upgrade from 1.3.1 to 1.4, and so we no longer will need to maintain them.  The second reason is that it will improve the speed of our functional tests, because every time we import data into JIRA (which is frequently), not only do our upgrade tasks have to run, but all the JIRA upgrade tasks have to run to upgrade from 3.12 to 3.13, and all the Confluence upgrade tasks have to run to upgrade from 2.7 to 2.9.
fields.summary: Refresh Initial Data

fields.description: After signing up on http://demo.jira.com, I don't see the Source and Reviews links.
fields.summary: demo.jira.com not displaying Source and Reviews headers

fields.description:
In the standard configuration, Studio will serve content over both http and https. When invoked over https, and the default logo is used, Internet Explorer complains on each page load, saying:

"This page contains both secure and nonsecure items Do you want to display the nonsecure items?"

This is because the default logo is served as:

http://<host>.jira.com/s/300/1/_/download/resources/com.atlassian.studio.static:studio_images/images/StudioLogo.gif

It should be a relative URL, so that whatever scheme is picked is used.
fields.summary: Logo hardcoded to http:// causes IE warning popup about "secure and nonsecure items"

fields.description: right now, we allow the user to specify app (all, issues, wiki) etc from the quick search, but not once they get into the search results page. Should allow it there as well.

fields.summary: Taskboard view in Greenhopper styled incorrectly

fields.description:
A customer has reported that occasionally their user loses permission to see project contents:

{quote}Last week we lost visibility to our projects. This issue cleaned itself up so I didn't open up an issue but it's happening again. The projects drop down and the projects portlet on the dashboard are not showing all of the projects. If I click on one of the projects that is showing, it gives me the following error:

ERROR
It seems that you have tried to perform an operation which you are not permitted to perform.

If you think this message is wrong, please consult your administrators about getting the necessary permissions.
{quote}

There is nothing in the Crowd or JIRA logs indicating a problem.
fields.summary: Intermittent loss of access to project contents

fields.description:
Tried to create a page in Confluence as Collab user and got message: This Confluence installation is not licensed for additional users
You have exceeded the maximum number of users for your license. You will still be able to view content, but in order to create or edit content, you must reduce the number of active users in the installation.

This is because a user cannot be deleted in JIRA in certain circumstances, and so JIRA doesn't count someone not assigned to any group.  Confluence does count the user, and prohibits page creation.
fields.summary: Confluence installation license counts users differently than JIRA

fields.description: Logging into the dashboard as Collab the activity stream produces these errors on the dashboard: Problem with FishEye portlet configuration: com.atlassian.configurable.ObjectConfigurationException: You must specify a FishEye repository to monitor AND There was an error gathering activity: Error getting activity from Crucible. UPDATE: this also happens on the project stream
fields.summary: Collaborator Problem with FishEye on dashboard
